text: hey everyone Anthony Fantino here the

question punchline Damon Albarn famed
singer-songwriter and

very very very familiar with his work
from bands like blur and gorillas they
dropped their last album a few years ago
actually Plastic Beach nice little
electro pop hip hop record fusion and a
great record to close things out before
Damon Albarn kind of put gorillas on an
indefinite hiatus but Anthony what about

what you're talking about total dick
well now the gorillas is on hold
Damon is focusing more on solo endeavors
which I mean it's cool even though Damon
Albarn isn't gorillas technically you
could in theory get just as excited over
a Damon Albarn solo LP considering that
he did a great deal of the songwriting
and the instrumentation that went into
those gorillas records so any solo Damon
Albarn material could feasibly be like
gorillas material right but that's not
really what happens here at all instead
with albums like dr. D he's embracing
his singer/songwriter side his opera
side his choral music side and with this
latest full-length LP of his his
singer/songwriter side remains but it is
much dreary er much more depressing and
electronically tinged to with synthetic
beats some of them are subtly glitchy I
guess you could say some of these tracks
are a little trip hop or downtempo but
no matter how far down that road Damon
goes on this LP this record still
doesn't stray away from that solo
singer/songwriter vibe too much and
overall this is a record whose music
perfectly reflects the cover the songs
here are grey they're moody heads down
no reason to look up no reason to like
look forward into the future the one
exception on this record though is the
song mr. tremble Oh which once it comes
on it is a huge
change of pace in that it feels like I'm
listening to Sunkist Caribbean flavored
island pop Damon's voice sounds a little
too weary to give it that upbeat feel
that it's really shooting for not to
mention the instrumentation sounds like
the Wiggles are playing it this track is
the one significant moment of emotional
variety in the middle of this record and
it falls flat on its face
the only other left hook on this record
is the closing track heavy seas of love
where Damon is actually still on his
choral pop kick maybe that actually
isn't too much of a left hook since that
was on his last record as well but still
it does vary from the formula of many
songs on this album and even though a
lot of the vocals on here feel a little
too theater they feel a little too train
I do think they add a lot to the song
and it is a beautiful song and Damon
sounds really passionate over the chorus
as he's singing the heavy seas of love
refrain even though the record is a
little hit or miss I do like that this
song comes through and and at least
leaves things off with a very big grand
feel good mood outside of those two
tracks the forecast for this record is
in the low 60s it's overcast there's a
drizzle with a slight chance of this
album is like listening to one long sigh
get let out over really beautiful
instrumentation it's so one-dimensional
in that regard and even though the the
depression it does feel very real this
record does feel very bleak it's it's
not so strong that it really grips me or
moves me emotionally it's just kind of
like I'm I'm listening to a fly buzz in
the room which I am inhabiting and I
don't know where the fly is I can't see
it but every once in a while I'm just
hearing just like this really annoying
emotional itch scratching in the back of
my head I would say that I have zero
patience for whatsoever if it weren't
for the fact that Damon actually backs
some of these gloomy moments up with
decent songs like the song everyday
robots the title track the opener on
this record I like the eerie string
melodies that are looped and played
throughout this song the patient be the
sad piano the rhythm is like a bit of a
noisy very colorful rhythmic
Trail Mix dis really nutty and vocally
this is one of the few moments where
demons blasé attitude actually is a
little intoxicating the lyrics do kind
of focus on the current world's follies
and technology which there were some
songs on Plastic Beach that dealt with
that these issues of modern identity
Damon essentially painting people as
everyday robots who are just going
through a routine and texting sexting
and if you really wanted to confirm the
sadness on this LP
no need to look any further than the
song lonely press play a song that's
kind of about music as a refuge at least
how I interpret it the groove is a
little smoother on this track than it is
on others acoustic guitars blend with
piano really nicely and this track has
of course the stuck in my head from
first listen and there's a moment
lyrically in the pre-chorus to this song
where Damon is singing a line that has
me thinking is is he singing about fans
sort of using his music as kind of like
a shoulder to cry on or something to
kind of get them through the day whether
he's reaching out to people who listen
to him or sort of just talking about
more of a personal experience it is a
beautiful track songs like hollow ponds
and photographs continue to impress me
from a songwriting standpoint however
there are tracks on here where there
isn't much about them other than the
instrumentation that grips me when it
comes to the vocal melody when it comes
to the lyrics
I mean Damon Albarn comes off pretty
uninteresting kind of boring just
nothing really to report like The
Selfish Giant and you and me
I love the distant fluttering flute

actually think the beat kind of

just literally more interesting than
what he's doing with his voice and then
with you and me while I do like the
descending keyboard melodies on that
track they're kind of weird odd
experimental I think they bring a lot of
flavor to the song there is a god-awful
steel drum solo in the middle of the

the song I'm assuming that the steel

isn't it is not a good addition to the
song overall
this record consistently brings
seductively sad songs with
instrumentation that is very smooth it's
tasteful its well assembled some of the
samples here and there feel a little
bulky but I think it adds to the glitchy
tone of the tracks the damon does make
these songs feel a little rough in some
respects despite their very soft nature
but as i've said sometimes through the
soft instrumentation a gripping song or
gripping melody or lyric doesn't even
shine through and while there are
highlights on this record good songs and
I do think this record is emotionally
potent at least when it comes to the

Damon's vocals are just a little too
drained in the way that I feel like
sometimes the vocals are a little too
drained on like a national record or
